oscarp package

Submodules

oscarp.cluster_manager module

oscarp.cluster_manager._apply_fdl_configuration_oscar()[source]

Applies the FDL configuration file through the OSCAR cli binary

Returns:

None

oscarp.cluster_manager.apply_fdl_configuration_wrapped()[source]

Applies the FDL configuration file, then verifies that all the required services have actually been deployed.

Returns:

None

oscarp.cluster_manager.clean_s3_buckets()[source]

Cleans the S3 buckets used by the lambda functions, if any are present. Updated 17/07/2023 after moving from SCAR to IM deployment.

Returns:

None

oscarp.cluster_manager.generate_fdl_configuration()[source]

Generates the FDL configuration file containing all the OSCAR services needed for the current test Lambda functions (old SCAR) are no longer included as they are deployed together with the infrastructures by IM.

Returns:

None

oscarp.cluster_manager.generate_fdl_storage_providers()[source]

Services deployed on different resources need to know the location of input bucket of the next service; this is done by including the used storage providers in the FDL configuration file. This info is extracted by the MinIO configuration file, which is filled after the resources are created.

Returns:

a dictionary containing the providers, ready to be added in the FDL file

oscarp.cluster_manager.generate_service_script(component_name)[source]

The bash script of the services is included inside their docker image (01/03/2023). The bash script supplied to OSCAR just needs to call said “real” script. These simple scripts are generated locally in an hidden folder called “.scripts”, and their path is added to the FDL file.

Returns:

path to the service script

oscarp.cluster_manager.get_deployed_services(oscarcli_alias)[source]

Gets the OSCAR services deployed on a certain resource.

Returns:

list of deployed services

oscarp.cluster_manager.remove_all_buckets()[source]

Removes all the buckets (aside from the storage bucket) for all resources that are not lambdas.

Returns:

None

oscarp.cluster_manager.remove_all_services()[source]

Removes all the services from all resources that are not lambdas.

Returns:

None

oscarp.cluster_manager.set_default_oscar_cluster_from_alias(oscarcli_alias)[source]

Sets a cluster as default for the OSCAR CLI binary; in this way the commands don’t need to specify on which cluster they need to be executed.

Returns:

None

oscarp.cluster_manager.upload_input_files_to_storage()[source]

Uploads the input files to the MinIO storage bucket on the resource of the first service.

Returns:

None

oscarp.cluster_manager.verify_correct_oscar_deployment()[source]

Starting from the list of active services, it makes sure that all of them are deployed.

Returns:

None

oscarp.gui module

oscarp.gui.append_to_deployment_summary(string)[source]

Receives a line and appends it to the summary.

Parameters:

string (str) – Output line, stripped of ANSI

Returns:

None

oscarp.gui.runs_diff_resources(run_name1, run_name2)[source]

Given two runs, it shows the difference in the number of nodes for each resource.

Parameters:

  • run_name1 (str) – name of the first run (e.g. “Run #1”)

  • run_name2 (str) – name of the second run

Returns:

None

oscarp.gui.runs_diff_services(run_name1, run_name2)[source]

Given two runs, it shows the difference in the parallelism level for each service.

Parameters:

  • run_name1 (str) – name of the first run (e.g. “Run #1”)

  • run_name2 (str) – name of the second run

Returns:

None

oscarp.gui.show_all_resources(run_index)[source]

For a given run, it shows for each resource the required number of nodes; it’s called for the first run only.

Parameters:

run_index (int) – run index

Returns:

None

oscarp.gui.show_all_services(run_index, repetitions)[source]

For a given run, it shows for each service their cpu, memory, parallelism level and resource; it’s called for the first run only.

Parameters:

  • run_index (int) – run index

  • repetitions (int) – number of repetitions

Returns:

None

oscarp.gui.show_and_save_to_summary(string)[source]

Receives a line, prints it and then appends it to the campaign summary.

Parameters:

string (str) – Output line

Returns:

None

oscarp.gui.show_runs()[source]

It combines the previous functions to show all the scheduled runs.

Returns:

None

oscarp.input_file_processing.show_workflow()[source]

From the list of the current services, it prints the workflow.

Returns:

None

oscarp.mllibrary_manager module

oscarp.mllibrary_manager.add_to_performance_models_json()[source]
oscarp.mllibrary_manager.make_prediction(config_file, workdir)[source]

this functions makes predictions by using the trained models :param config_file: points to aMLLibrary-predict.ini :param workdir: points to the currently considered model (e.g. Models/Interpolation/full_model_noSFS)

oscarp.mllibrary_manager.run_mllibrary()[source]
oscarp.mllibrary_manager.set_mllibrary_config_path(config_file, filepath)[source]

this function sets the correct path to the train set in the SFS or noSFS configuration file :param config_file: path to the configuration file :param filepath: path to the test set csv

oscarp.mllibrary_manager.set_mllibrary_predict_path(config_file, filepath)[source]

this function sets the correct path to the test set in the “predict” configuration file :param config_file: path to the configuration file :param filepath: path to the test set csv

oscarp.mllibrary_manager.train_and_predict(dataframes_dir, models_dir, run_name)[source]

this function trains the regressors, both with and without SFS, and then makes the predictions :param dataframes_dir: points to either CSVs/Interpolation or CSVs/Extrapolation and makes this function reusable :param models_dir: points to either Models/Interpolation or Models/Extrapolation :param run_name:

oscarp.mllibrary_manager.train_models(config_file, filepath, output_dir)[source]

this function train the four regressors, either with or without SFS depending on the parameters :param config_file: path to the configuration file :param filepath: path to the test set csv :param output_dir: output directory for the four regressors (i.e. “Models/Extrapolation/full_model_noSFS”) :return:

oscarp.oscarp module

oscarp.oscarp.end_run_full(current_run_index)[source]
oscarp.oscarp.final_processing()[source]
oscarp.oscarp.main()[source]
oscarp.oscarp.manage_campaign_dir()[source]
if the campaign_dir already exists, and a “Results” folder is present, it exits, otherwise it finds the last

run (i.e. “Run #11”), it deletes it (it may have failed) and resumes from there if the run_dir doesn’t exist it creates it and starts as normal

Returns:

the index of the next run to execute; this is the index from the list “runs”, not the run id (i.e. run with index 0 has id “Run #1”)

oscarp.oscarp.prepare_clusters()[source]

Prepares the cluster for the new test by removing the leftover services and bucket, then generating and applying the new FDL configuration. It also uploads the input files to the storage bucket on the resource of the first service, if the test is asynchronous.

Returns:

None

oscarp.oscarp.process_subfolder()[source]
oscarp.oscarp.start_run_full()[source]
oscarp.oscarp.test_single_lambda()[source]

oscarp.postprocessing module

oscarp.postprocessing.calculate_average(values)[source]

receives a list of values, returns the average :param values: list of values :return: average

oscarp.postprocessing.calculate_maximum_parallelism(run)[source]

checks the resources of every service in a run and returns the parallelism level of the “most parallel” service :param run: dictionary containing info on a specific run, such as the number of nodes, the list and configuration of services :return: the parallelism level of the “most parallel” service

oscarp.postprocessing.calculate_parallelism(cores, max_cores, memory, max_memory, nodes)[source]

given the number of nodes, the maximum number of cores and the used number of core, it returns the parallelism level, that is the maximum possible number of containers that can run together at the same time :param cores: number of active cores (i.e. 0.9, 1.9, 3.9) :param max_cores: total number of cores on a node (i.e. 4) :param nodes: number of active nodes :return: the maximum possible number of containers that can run together at the same time

oscarp.postprocessing.calculate_runtime(working_dir, services)[source]

given the directory of a specific run (i.e. “Run #1/”) and the list of services, it returns the runtime of that run; the list of services is ordered, so it doesn’t need too many checks

Parameters:

  • working_dir – directory of a specific run (i.e. “Run #1/”)

  • services – ordered list of services, each a dictionary containing name of the service (as string), input bucket (as string) and output buckets (list of strings)

Returns:

runtime of the run in seconds

oscarp.postprocessing.find_best_model(workdir)[source]

called by find_best_prediction, returns the name of the best model, its mape, and a summary (as list of string) containing the mape of all other models :param workdir: path to two directories of the currently considered models (with and without SFS) :returns: name of best model, best mape, summary of other models performance

oscarp.postprocessing.find_best_prediction(workdir, summary_path)[source]

called by find_best_predictions, given two model directories (each contains 4 regressors) returns the predictions of the best model :param workdir: path to two directories of the currently considered models (with and without SFS) :param summary_path: path to the summary text file :return: a dictionary containing info on predictions such as the name of the best model, its mape and the predicted values

oscarp.postprocessing.find_best_predictions(results_dir, run_name)[source]

called by plot_ml_predictions_graphs, returns two dictionaries containing the predictions made with the best models :param results_dir: path to the “Results” folder of the considered campaign :param run_name: :returns: two dictionary, one for interpolation and one for extrapolation, each containing info on predictions such as the name of the best model, its mape and the predicted values

oscarp.postprocessing.get_first_job(timelist)[source]

returns the time of the creation of the first job in a given timelist

Parameters:

timelist – dictionary containing a list of jobs, each job itself a dictionary containing the following info: service, node, job_create, pod_create, job_start, bash_script_start, bash_script_end, job_finish; timelists are created by function “get_timed_jobs_list” in file “retrieve_logs.py”

Returns:

the time of the creation (job_create) of the first job as datetime

oscarp.postprocessing.get_last_job(timelist)[source]

returns the time of the completion of the last job in a given timelist

Parameters:

timelist – dictionary containing a list of jobs, each job itself a dictionary containing the following info: service, node, job_create, pod_create, job_start, bash_script_start, bash_script_end, job_finish; timelists are created by function “get_timed_jobs_list” in file “retrieve_logs.py”

Returns:

the time of the completion (job_finish) of the last job as datetime

oscarp.postprocessing.load_dataframes(results_dir, subfolder)[source]

loads the dataframe and averaged_dataframe for a specific subfolder of a specific campaign :param results_dir: path to the “Results” folder of the considered campaign :param subfolder: specifies whether we’re considering the full workflow (“full”) or a service

oscarp.postprocessing.make_runtime_core_csv(results_dir, run_name, df)[source]

writes the dataframe as CSV that can be fed to the ML library

Parameters:

  • results_dir – path to the “Results” folder of the considered campaign

  • subfolder – specifies whether we’re considering the full workflow (“full”) or a service

  • df – dataframe containing the runtime/parallelism data for every run (including repetitions)

oscarp.postprocessing.make_runtime_core_csv_for_ml(results_dir, data, averaged_data, operation)[source]

generates the training and test set for the interpolation (or extrapolation) tests of a campaign :param results_dir: path to the “Results” folder of the considered campaign :param data: complete dataframe with all values obtained in the campaign, used for the training set :param averaged_data: reduced dataframe with averaged values, used for the test set :param operation: specifies whether we are performing Interpolation or Extrapolation

oscarp.postprocessing.make_statistics(campaign_dir, results_dir, subfolder, services)[source]

for every operation of a service (wait, overhead, compute etc.) calculates its mean, average, variance, population standard deviation and coefficient of variation, saved in a text file under “Results/Statistics”

Parameters:

  • campaign_dir – path to the current campaign folder, containing all the “Run #i” folders as well as the “Results” folder

  • results_dir – path to the “Results” folder of the considered campaign

  • subfolder – specifies whether we’re considering the full workflow (“full”) or a service

  • services – ordered list of services, each a dictionary containing name of the service (as string), input bucket (as string) and output buckets (list of strings)

oscarp.postprocessing.merge_csv_of_service(campaign_dir, service_name)[source]

for all the runs in a campaign, merges together the CSV files of a specified service :param campaign_dir: path to the current campaign folder, containing all the “Run #i” folders as well as the “Results” folder :param service_name: name of the considered service

oscarp.postprocessing.plot_ml_predictions_graph(graphs_dir, subfolder, test_values, dictionary, df, adf, operation)[source]

plots a graph with all the runs, a line for the average and red marks for the predictions :param graphs_dir: directory containing the graphs of the considered campaign (i.e. “Results/Graphs”) :param subfolder: specifies whether we’re considering the full workflow (“full”) or a service :param test_values: array with the “parallelism” values used to make the predictions on :param dictionary: contains info on the prediction, such as the best model, its mape, and the predicted values :param df: dataframe containing the runtime/parallelism data for every run (including repetitions) :param adf: dataframe containing the runtime/parallelism data for every run (repeated runs are averaged) :param operation: string, is either “interpolation” or “extrapolation”, only needed to save the image

oscarp.postprocessing.plot_ml_predictions_graphs(results_dir, run_name)[source]

collects the required data needed to plot the ml graphs, such as test values, dataframes and predictions :param results_dir: path to the “Results” folder of the considered campaign :param run_name:

oscarp.postprocessing.plot_runtime_core_graphs(results_dir, run_name, df, adf)[source]

plots a graph with all the runs and a line for the average :param results_dir: path to the “Results” folder of the considered campaign :param subfolder: specifies whether we’re considering the full workflow (“full”) or a service :param df: dataframe containing the runtime/parallelism data for every run (including repetitions) :param adf: dataframe containing the runtime/parallelism data for every run (repeated runs are averaged)

oscarp.postprocessing.prepare_runtime_data(repetitions, runs, services)[source]

outputs two runtime/parallelism dataframes: * the first contains every run (including repetitions) * the second one instead averages the repeated runs

Parameters:

  • repetitions – number of times each run is repeated

  • runs – list of runs, each run being a dictionary containing info such as the number of nodes, the list and configuration of services

  • services – ordered list of services, each a dictionary containing name of the service (as string), input bucket (as string) and output buckets (list of strings)

Returns:

two runtime/parallelism dataframes, complete and averaged

oscarp.postprocessing.read_csv_content(filepath)[source]

returns the content of a csv file :param filepath: path to the csv file :returns: content of specified csv file

oscarp.postprocessing.read_csv_header(filepath)[source]

returns the header of a csv file :param filepath: path to the csv file :returns: header of specified csv file

oscarp.postprocessing.save_dataframes(results_dir, run_name, df, adf)[source]

saves the two dataframes to file so that they can be reused (when making the prediction graphs for example) :param results_dir: path to the “Results” folder of the considered campaign :param subfolder: specifies whether we’re considering the full workflow (“full”) or a service :param df: dataframe containing the runtime/parallelism data for every run (including repetitions) :param adf: dataframe containing the runtime/parallelism data for every run (repeated runs are averaged)
